awd_titl_txt: SpecEES: Unified System Architecture for Energy Efficient Cognitive Radios
awd_abstract_narration:
Although long envisioned to dramatically improve spectrum utilization and to safely share multiple frequency bands without interfering with licensed users, building and deploying energy efficient cognitive radios with dynamic spectrum access have proven to be a challenging task. This project proposes an energy-efficient cognitive radio system that addresses its many practical challenges including a low-power wideband radio that operates in multiple frequency bands and a means to seamlessly and efficiently coordinate the operating bands between communicating unlicensed users. The proposed work presents a complete integrated solution, ranging from radio implementation, signal processing algorithm development, and network connectivity. These different layers of abstraction have been jointly optimized to enable a low-power and robust cognitive radio system.

The proposed energy-efficient cognitive radio (CR) system, which is jointly optimized at the circuit, signal processing, and network layers, operates as follows: 1) A secondary user (SU) employs a novel compressed sampling receiver based on polyphase sequences implemented via mixer harmonics to sense concurrently the entire frequency span of interest. 2) Since the communicating band between SUs is unknown, data is transmitted by sending the same signal at low power levels across the entire frequency span of interest while nulling energy in the primary user (PU) bands. A novel sub-Nyquist transmitter, which can be viewed as a dual of the compressed sensing receiver, is proposed for this purpose. 3) The receiving SU uses the same compressed sampling receiver for sensing PUs to receive the SU signals. This is achieved by projecting the received signals to PU's null space, whose frequency locations were estimated during sensing. By appropriately selecting the basis functions set in the analog front-end, most of the received energy can be added coherently. 4) As SU energy is spread across the entire frequency span of interest, the resulting channel impulse response (CIR) is richly scattered. The CIR itself, therefore, can be used as users' signatures for achieving multiple-access communications. Furthermore, by leveraging on techniques from multiuser detection theory, high spectral efficiency can be achieved.

por.por_cntn:
Amidst escalating competition for the Radio Frequency (RF) spectrum, driven by an ever-increasing number of devices and services, efficient management and utilization of this finite resource have become critical. Our project tackles this challenge by enhancing both the signaling techniques and sensing of the wireless spectrum. Two major activities were pursued. In the first, we developed approaches to address many of the practical issues of sub-Nyquist receivers, which are low-power receivers that operate at frequencies below the minimum necessary. Our second set of activities focused on improving the traditional spectrum sensing scanner, which consists of sequentially scanning across a desired frequency range.    

Sub-Nyquist reception techniques have been widely studied by researchers for spectrum sensing due to their power efficiency. In this project, we tackled some of the practical challenges that arise when sub-Nyquist receivers are employed. These challenges include the overhead of control channels, spectrum sensing when users are unsynchronized, and the distortion resulting from out-of-band interferers. To address these challenges, signal processing algorithms that operate at sub-Nyquist rates, a new signaling scheme that seamlessly establish a communication link without the need for any side information, and a receiver architecture that is robust to out-of-band interferers have been devised.

The second category of our research activities was driven in large part by our finding that the traditional spectrum sweeping (SS) scanner, which sequentially senses across spectral frequencies, can be made significantly more efficient than the more advanced sensing technology referred to as compressed sensing (CS). While CS scanners were previously thought to outperform SS scanners in sparsely populated RF spectra, our findings challenge that assumption. Moreover, the robustness of SS scanner across various RF spectrum conditions makes them highly appealing compared to the CS scanners. In addition to performing a rigorous comparative study, we devised two promising SS architectures that have been optimized for rapid sensing. Considering both the implementation and performance advantages, we anticipate that our findings will inspire renewed research efforts aimed at enhancing SS scanners for dynamic spectrum access.

Beyond technical contributions, our project has enabled the training of students across varying educational levels. Students worked on various aspects of the project including hardware and algorithm development. The diverse group of students with different technical backgrounds working together has provided an interactive teamwork environment, allowing students to learn different topics from each other. Additionally, the project has enabled the development of a much-needed chip design framework that was previously unavailable at the University at Albany. As we integrate this into our teaching curriculum (which is a work in progress), it should greatly enhance students’ training in the crucial field of chip design.
